entry.title: Shoden-ji・正伝時
entry.content:
View of the rock garden at Shoden-ji Temple, in the very northern part of Kyoto.

Notice that the foliage behind the garden has been designed to frame Mt. Hiei in the distance. This is an example of “borrowed scenery” used in Japanese gardens.

entry.title: Shaved Ice・かき氷
entry.content:
A sign for Shaved Ice, Kakigori; a sign of summer.

Kakigori is a dessert, a giant mound of shaved ice, generally flavored with syrup or fruit; but tea, coffee, nuts, chocolate... the sky is the limit.

In the hands of the best chefs, it’s more like eating freshly fallen snow; fluffy, not crunchy; refreshing!
entry.summary: A sign for Shaved Ice, Kakigori; a sign of summer.
